text:
**Discharge Letter:**

Patient Name: Jane Smith  
Age: 62  
Date of Admission: 2024-02-10  
Date of Discharge: 2024-02-17  

Dear Dr. Patel,

I am writing to inform you of the discharge of Ms. Jane Smith, a 62-year-old female who was admitted to our hospital on February 10, 2024, with complaints of persistent cough, fever, and fatigue. Upon admission, Ms. Smith was promptly evaluated by our medical team.

During her hospitalization, Ms. Smith underwent a series of diagnostic procedures, including a chest CT scan, sputum culture, and blood tests. The results indicated evidence of pneumonia, prompting initiation of appropriate antibiotic therapy.

On February 12, 2024, Ms. Smith's condition deteriorated, necessitating transfer to the intensive care unit (ICU) for closer monitoring and respiratory support. She remained in the ICU for three days, during which her oxygen saturation levels were closely monitored and supplemental oxygen was administered as needed.

Ms. Smith showed gradual improvement in her respiratory status, and on February 16, 2024, she was transferred back to the general medical ward for further observation. Daily chest X-rays were performed to monitor the resolution of pulmonary infiltrates, which showed progressive improvement over the subsequent days.

After seven days of hospitalization, Ms. Smith's symptoms had significantly improved, and she was deemed medically stable for discharge on February 17, 2024. She was provided with a prescription for oral antibiotics to complete her course of treatment at home, along with instructions for follow-up with her primary care physician.

We anticipate a favorable recovery for Ms. Smith and recommend close monitoring of her symptoms to ensure continued improvement.

Sincerely,

[Physician's Signature]  
Dr. Sarah Johnson  
Pulmonologist
